ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: This is a great way to work on a real-world project with ample support from faculty members.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: The opportunity to work with real client was useful.
The highlight of this class is the project. What you sow is what you reap. The more effort you put into the project, the more you will be benefited from it.
Travelling to meet the client
Working with a client organization was a great way to dig deeply into a topic that interests me, and to learn about how to work with a small group on a consulting project.
I felt strongly supported by faculty members to complete a project that I am proud of.

This class offers a great opportunity to complete research and work to answer many pressing environmental questions. I benefited from the collaborative relationship I built with my team members and the frequent communication with my supervisor and client.
Practice consulting, real life experience with a client, a chance to delve more deeply into research about something that matters to a student.

The best part of this course is the professional experience it provides to students. I feel like this course will be much more useful to me in the long run than many other FES courses I've taken. It also provides students who are interested in underrepresented areas (like marine policy) with an avenue to study that topic and develop useful skills for their careers.
Working directly with clients. Feeling useful.

This course is fantastic - there are a variety of projects with employers all over the US and the world to choose from, so you get to work on a subject you care about while having the support of excellent faculty. As a bonus, you may get to work with a potential future employer.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: The class lectures can be made more useful to individual projects. In case where they can't, students should be allowed to skip those sessions.

Some of the classes were unnecessary. More discussion time should be afforded. Half of the class were in Advanced EPC and they barely showed up. It would be nice for different students together and seek synergy. As of now, the course structure is quite hierarchical.
Can't think of many.
My client did not provide very clear expectations to the clinic, and as a result my team's direction changed throughout the semester.
None, in my opinion. The course was great.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: As a clinic course, the lectures can be reduced to give more time for projects.
Juliana the TA is on top of running the project deadlines. It is very helpful.

I think it would be impossible to present lectures that were relevant to all groups' projects; I appreciated learning about different areas of environmental law even when they weren't explicitly related to my particular project.
At times, the course meetings did not seem as relevant to our individual research questions.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: The course helped me to meet the capstone requirement for the degree.

I think how this course fits into my program really depends on if the project fits into my career goal. In my case, it did. I have learned a tremendous amount of information on my project and has gotten a clear picture on the field that I researched on.
This course provided me with one of the only opportunities at F&ES to work on a project related to fisheries management.
This course allowed me to apply specific topical knowledge to a real world project - I know have a solid work product to show for the research I have been doing as a student.
I'm a JD/MEM, so this course fits perfectly with my program.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: No.
I want to study at a law school clinic and get some project-based experience.
Clinical project experience
I was specifically interested in working on a project focused on fisheries, and my EPC project provided a great way to get hands-on experience in fisheries management.
To work with a specific client on a project I brought in.
I wanted to challenge myself and gain more independent research skills. The opportunity to participate in a long-term project was also very appealing to me.
A specific client involved in the EPC reached out to me about a project related to my interests.

I took this course because I wanted to gain professional experience in marine policy. Additionally, FES has a woefully underdeveloped curriculum for students interested in oceans compared to competitors from which it allegedly hopes to recruit prospective students (Duke & UCSB). I don't think FES will address this (damaging and frankly misguided) gap anytime soon, but until then EPC provides the perfect opportunity for ocean-focused FES students to work on marine policy projects for academic credit.
I was interested in taking a clinic.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: The project I took was something I had some background in so it helped me to understand the different aspects of the project better.
I have benefited a lot from the project, though I hope that there could be more supervision.
Yes
Yes
Yes

Yes. The independence students have as they work on their project is a very valuable teaching tool. I learned a lot about my own time management and organizational skills, and identified areas where I can improve. I also built a relationship with a great marine conservation non-profit, which I hope to use in the future for networking/job-hunting/general information. All in all, I got exactly what I wanted from this course.
Yes--probably one of the most valuable classes I've taken at FES.
Yes.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: The group work is arguably the highlight of the course. With the right project, the course can be extremely fulfilling. In my case, I have benefited from my project and it opens a door to further career development.
Ability to work on a team as part of a larger project. Difficulties arose from balancing abilities, knowledge and time to give to the project.
We all had very different skills and interests which made the project more interesting

Though working on a semester-long group project is challenging, I learned a great deal about how to manage time through setting benchmarks and meeting agendas, and dividing tasks between the three of us.

I grew a lot from my collaboration in this course. The most challenging aspect of group work was managing expectations. I felt insecure about my understanding of legal research throughout the semester because I worried that my work would not measure up to that of my YLS colleague. My biggest personal lesson came from appreciating the different strengths we all brought to our team.
It was a really great group experience. Scheduling has been very challenging, but otherwise I have no complaints.

Advantages included having others to bounce your ideas off of and spread the work around. Disadvantages included varying levels of familiarity/expertise with the project material. I found that even within our team we developed "silos," i.e. where certain students were doing exclusively legal research and others were doing scientific research. I don't think there was any feasible way to avoid this in a short (semester) timespan, but I do think these types of silos are a chronic problem in environmental conservation/policy. I wished I'd had time to dive into the material I wasn't familiar with, in addition to the material that I felt comfortable researching. In a professional setting I hope I will have the ability to do this.
Group work in the clinic is the same as working on a professional team - you don't necessarily choose who you're working with, and they can be great, frustrating, or both.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Carefully select your project and make sure you are clear on what you have to deliver.
Really work on you project. You won't regret it.
Find a project that fits your interests
Great selection of projects, great teaching staff.
This is an excellent course for anyone interested in testing out an organization, working on a specific project with implications outside of academia, or learning how to serve as a consultant.
Prepare for a heavy workload and don't procrastinate.
This course requires long-term, consistent work and a large time investment.
Make sure you pick an appropriate client to work with (i.e. one who has something you're actually interested in!) and schedule EPC research time into your weekly schedule.

Work hard, log your hours, communicate with your clients. Stay on the ball and if you feel like something isn't right (unclear project goals, undetermined deadlines, etc), speak up--not doing so will be much worse in the long run.
Take it, but select your project wisely...

This clinic offers a variety of projects - whatever your expertise or program focus, if you're interested in environmental protection there's probably something interesting for you to work on in the clinic.
